Virtual Class BernsteinFunction for Bernstein Functions

Source: R/allClass-S4.R, R/valueOf-S4.R
BernsteinFunction-class.Rd

A virtual superclass for all implementations of the various classes of Bernstein functions which have a representaion $$ \psi(x) = a + b x + \int_0^\infty (1 - e^{-ux}) \nu(du) , x > 0 $$ for non-negative constants \(a, b \geq 0\), called killing rate and drift, and a Lévy measure \(\nu\) on \((0, \infty)\).

valueOf(object, x, difference_order = 0L, n = 1L, k = 0L, cscale = 1, ...)

uexIntensities(object, d, ...)

intensities(object, d, ...)

exIntensities(object, d, ...)

exQMatrix(object, d, ...)

# S4 method for BernsteinFunction
uexIntensities(object, d, ...)

# S4 method for BernsteinFunction
exIntensities(object, d, ...)

# S4 method for BernsteinFunction
intensities(object, d, ...)

# S4 method for BernsteinFunction
exQMatrix(object, d, ...)

Arguments

object

An object deriving from LevyBernsteinFunction (for levyDensity) or CompleteBernsteinFunction (for stieltjesDensity).

x

Non-negativ numeric vector at which the iterated difference of the Bernstein function is evaluated.

difference_order

The order of the alternating iterated forward differences taken on the Bernstein function (\(j\) in the representation).

n, k

Non-negative numbers for the binomial factors.

cscale

Positive number, the composit scaling factor.

...

Pass-through parameter

d

Dimension

Details

Bernstein functions have a 1-1 relationship to Lévy subordinators s.t. for every Bernstein function \(\psi\), there exists a Lévy subordinator \(\Lambda\) with $$ E[e^{-x \Lambda_t}] = e^{-t \psi(x)} , t, x > 0 . $$

  • \(a\) Describes the (exponential) killing rate, which determines the rate of an exponentially distributed event that sends the subordinator to infinity.

  • \(b\) Describes the linear drift of the Lévy subordinator.

  • \(\nu\) determines the arrival-rate and shock-size distribution for the jumps of the Lévy subordinator.

For a theoretic treatment of Bernstein function, we refer to (Schilling et al. 2012) .

The method valueOf is implemented different, depending on the specific Bernstein function to get the best possible accuracy:

  • For difference_order == 0L, the values are calculated with closed form formulas if possible.

  • For linear Bernstein functions and constant Bernstein functions the iterated differences are calculated automatically.

  • For scaled Bernstein functions and sums of Bernstein functions the result is calculted recursively.

  • For all other cases, the values are calculated using either the Lévy-Khintchine or the Stieltjes representation. Which one is chosen, depends on the case and can be manually overwritten with method = "levy" or method = "stieltjes".

Functions

  • valueOf: Calculate the values for a compound scaled Bernstein function and its higher-order, alternating iterated forward differences, possibly scaled by a binomial $$ {(-1)}^{j-1} \Delta^j \psi(c x), x > 0. $$

  • uexIntensities: Calculates (unscaled) exchangeable shock arrival intensities, see rmo() and rexmo().

  • intensities: Calculates intensities parameter for rmo().

  • exIntensities: Calculates (scaled) exchangeable shock-size arrival intensities for rexmo().

  • exQMatrix: Calculates the infinitesimal generator matrix of the corresponding Markovian default-counting process used internally by rexmo().

References

Schilling RL, Song R, Vondracek Z (2012). Bernstein functions, 2 edition. De Gruyter. doi: 10.1515/9783110269338 .

See also

LevyBernsteinFunction, CompleteBernsteinFunction, ConstantBernsteinFunction, ScaledBernsteinFunction, SumOfBernsteinFunctions, LinearBernsteinFunction, PoissonBernsteinFunction, AlphaStableBernsteinFunction, ExponentialBernsteinFunction, InverseGaussianBernsteinFunction, GammaBernsteinFunction, ParetoBernsteinFunction

Examples

exIntensities(AlphaStableBernsteinFunction(4e-1), 3L)
#> [1] 0.6970130 0.2615107 0.5933218

exIntensities(AlphaStableBernsteinFunction(4e-1), 3L)
#> [1] 0.6970130 0.2615107 0.5933218

intensities(AlphaStableBernsteinFunction(4e-1), 3L)
#> [1] 0.23233766 0.23233766 0.08717025 0.23233766 0.08717025 0.08717025 0.59332184

exQMatrix(AlphaStableBernsteinFunction(4e-1), 3L)
#>           [,1]      [,2]       [,3]      [,4]
#> [1,] -1.551846  0.697013  0.2615107 0.5933218
#> [2,]  0.000000 -1.319508  0.6390158 0.6804921
#> [3,]  0.000000  0.000000 -1.0000000 1.0000000
#> [4,]  0.000000  0.000000  0.0000000 0.0000000
